content:
30, 2014
												Reviewing a remake of a game that is over ten years old is a little difficult, especially if the remake is nearly an exact copy of the original game.  In this case, “Age of Mythology: Extended Edition” is nearly identical.  Everything from the character models to the level design remain the same.  Don’t get me wrong, it looks much prettier than I remember it…but aside from the extras, you’re getting the same game you played years prior.  Same scoop of vanilla ice cream if you will, but with jimmies and chocolate syrup on top.  Shadows, lighting, water effects, time of day, antialiasing, ambient occlusion…all great additions, I just wish there was a bit more.  Twitch users will be pleased to know that there is Twitch integration, though I personally haven’t tried it to know if it works.With that being said, I do appreciate the remake, even if it’s almost the same game as I played years ago.  Seeing the updated graphics was nice, though I admit the appeal was mainly centered around the fact that I didn’t have to enter my blasted serial key each time I wanted to install the game.  I also don’t have to worry about managing discs…all three products (“Age of Mythology”, “Age of Mythology: The Titans”, “Golden Gift Campaign”) were all condensed into one nice, easy to boot up package.  It’s hard to justify that convenience into a thirty dollar price tag however, the going rate as of 4/29/14.  If you’ve never played “Age of Mythology”, love RTS’s, and don’t mind the outdated character models/interface, then picking this up is most certainly worth your time and money. If you have your own playable copies of the game from years ago and want to know if buying the extended edition for the effects is worth thirty bucks, then I’d have to say (with heartfelt regret) no.Full Review:http://www.dadsgamingaddiction.com/age-of-mythology-extended-edition/Gameplay Video:

content:
er 16, 2014
												Age of Mythology is the classic, mythology based spinoff of Age of Empires, and boy was it fun. But does Age of Mythology  Extended Edition live up to the original? In many ways, very much so, though the price tag might dissaude you unless you're a huge fan, (like I am). If you've played Age of Mythology before, you know exactly how this game works. If not, here a basic gist of it. It plays much like Age of Empires 2; you have to collect resources, specifically food, wood and gold, in order to fund your armies, economies, technologies and advancement. sounds basic enough, and all the races work similarly in regards to these resources. The difference comes in the fourth resource: Favour. Favour is generated differently depending on which race you are playing. For instance, the greeks generate favour through worship, the egyptians through building monuments, the norse through heroes and fighting, and the atlanteans through having more settlements. Favour is the special resource, which ties into the major mechanic of Age of Mythology: Gods and God Powers. There are 12 major gods, 3 for each of the races, and these determine starting bonuses for you when you start the game. the gods also have minor gods to choose each time you advance an age, with a total of 36 minor gods, each offering different bonuses and god powers. For instance Hades gives you the Sentinel God Power, that creates stone sentinels to watch over your town centre, but in the second age, you can choose Athena, who allows you to train minotaurs and the Restoration God power which can heal your units.Aside from the new favour mechanic, for the major part it plays like the age of empires games. Build Army, upgrade, and take care of your population cap and economy. Rock paper scissors, for basic units, (cavalry beats archers who beat infantry), but add heroes and myth units which can turn the tide of battle. Both the singleplayer and multiplayer are fun, and with the new release, there is a rebirth in the multiplayer, though not as big as the heyday of AoM. As being essentially a remake (a la Age of Empires 2 HD Edition), AoM:EE is actually fairly bug free, and while it definitely shows its age, the added subtle lighting effects, water and shadows do help to make look better. It is definitely very playable, and for fans of the original, it shouldn't even be a bother.The campaign is just as memeroable as always, a hunt through Greece, Egypt, Scandinavia and finally Atlantis in order to stop a power hungry cyclops from releasing Kronos, King of the Titans; followed by A New Atlantis, set a number of years later,  where you are tricked into releasing the Titans, and must stop them at all costs . Overall, Age of Mythology: Extended Editon is fun, unique and offers up plenty of value, with 50 singleplayer missions, skrimishes, and now revived multiplayer, though for those who still have a copy of Age of Mythology and The Titans expansion, it might not add a great deal. Definitely recommend everyone else (who's a fan of older RTSes).

content:
y 29, 2016
												Ordinarily, I don't write reviews - but I've always been pretty invested in the Ensemble Studios games and seeing what Microsoft and Skybox have done with one of their all-time legends has pushed me into comment.Age of Mythology: Extended Edition. Ordinarily, to extend something means to prolong it or make it bigger somehow but if you're hoping for new content, this game does not have any. It's just the same game you played back in 2003 - but that's not so bad, because that game was great. This however, isn't - and there's some vital reasons as to why:1 - The Multiplayer. The most important aspect of any Real Time Strategy game is its multiplayer community and Age of Mythology has always had a creative and thriving one. This Extended Edition would too - if the multiplayer actually worked. You don't need me to tell you, just go check out the Support forum for this game. The game suffers from consistent crashes, desync, stuttering, framedrops and lag when attempting an online game. The developers blame "ancient bugs" left over from the original game despite the fact that none of these bugs were actually present in the 2003 release and accusing the now defunct Ensemble Studios (thanks Microsoft) for being responsible for your own mistakes is downright cowardly. disrespectful and lazy especially seeing as you're now flogging their product to an unaware market.2 - The Single Player. The AI during Single Player matches is bizarre, eclectic and at often times completely incomprehensible. Prone to suddenly stopping all activity halfway through a match for completely banal reasons (there was no food in their line of sight, you spawned too close to them etc) every Random Match is essentially a roll-of-the-dice of whether or not the AI feels like playing along this time. This problem has only been made worse by the addition of the new, COMPULSORY DLC which has 'updated' the AI to coincide with the introduction of a new civilization. Unfortunately, those who don't purchase the DLC are still obligated to download the patch, meaning they suffer from all of the bugs whilst receiving none of the reward.3 - The DLC.  Most likely what drew you to this Steam page in the first place seeing as this game hasn't seen a real increase in playerbase in almost a year. I followed the development of the DLC for a good few months and have been heavily invested in it. The attitude of the developers and their 'effort' as far as producing quality content goes is detestable. Aside from the rather invested and community-involved attitude from those at ForgottenEmpires (a small team of fans), comment and involvement from the lead developers (Skybox) has consisted of grade-1 ♥♥♥♥-all. They spent a good few months assuring us the DLC would contain strictly new, fresh content without any reskinning, repackaging or rebranding of existing content and that turned out to be a complete lie. They also lied about having playtested the game for balance - admitting during a public streaming of the game (you can find it on Youtube) that they purposefully left the DLC broken and unbalanced as a means of making people have to play it. The DLC itsels is incredibly broken as of writing this (again, check the Support forum), with half the playerbase unable to access the DLC at all and the other half jokingly trying to laugh off the regret of their purchase.One of the developers admitted on the Subreddit that they are currently "using the public to beta test the game" - meaning that if you buy this DLC you are not getting content, you are buying into the opportunity to test unfinished content. This coupled with the fact that the developers openly laughed at the idea of fixing the Multiplayer (again, check the stream) tells me that we aren't dealing with incompetent developers - we're dealing with scam artists.I don't like having to write this sort of stuff about any Ensemble Studios IP because it sucks seeing their legacy ♥♥♥♥ on by untalented coat-tail riders, but if it means discouraging people from wasting their money on what is essentially a gigantic bug test, then it feels somewhat worthwhile. Only buy this if you absolutely *must* play Age of Mythology again and don't want to go through the effort of pirating the old copy and getting it to work - but know that this is not the Age of Mythology you played ten years ago and it certainly is not a well-supported or active game.

content:
, 2016
												\ Ignore the amount of hours I have here, I've played the original game and the Titans expansion for hundreds of hours. / - THOSE WHO HAVE PLAYED THE ORIGINAL GAME SKIP THE FIRST PARAGRAPH - Age of Mythology is a simple strategy game to get into, but hard to master. The game has 3 campaigns (although not the same length) and PvP multiplayer (Online, AI and LAN). The first campaign alone (32 levels) is a lot of fun and the story is very interesting; it will take more than 30 hours to complete this campaign alone! Add on the Titans campaign and another one (which I haven't played yet) and you can easily get over 60 hours of play-time.The multiplayer is nice and easy to set up and a lot of fun and very competitive.The mechanics are pretty much the same as any other RTS (Real Time Strategy) game: gather resources, build a big city and army, and finally demolish the enemy. Unlike other RTS games I have tried in the past, the game is easy to learn and the UI is very well set out and organised: you will rarely, if never, get confused as to what's going on or what you're supposed to do to advance/beat the level.Now, I'll talk about the remastering of the game.The game is pretty much the same, apart from the inclusion of the expansions straight away; you won't find anything new gameplay-wise or content-wise. What has improved is the support for high screen resolutions (including multi-monitor setups, which I have tried myself and... oh boy... it's faboulous), better shadows and lighting. A cool addition is the ability to stream on Twitch directly from the game; I haven't tried doing so myself but I think it's a nice feature.Lastly, there's Mods. Still have to play around with them, but as far as I've seen there's some quality stuff.\ VERDICT /If you have played Age of Mythology before and want to re-experience everything again and compete against other players, this game won't disappoint you. BUY THIS GAME.But if you're expecting new stuff, you're out of luck.If you have never played Age of Mythology you're missing out a lot. BUY THIS GAME.If you have played any Age of Empires game and you enjoyed them BUY THIS GAME.This is the longest review I've ever written on Steam.

content:
er 23, 2014
												As you see I've spent over 600 hours playing this game, and that is not even a lot when you compare it to the time I played the original game for. Definitely had to re-write my review since my other one was made after 30 gameplay hours.Age of Mythology takes you into one of the most unique and timeless RTS experiences I have ever seen. You have to pick between 4 civilizations: the Greek, Egyptian, Norse and Atlantean - each have 3 major gods to pick from. There are 4 ages to guide your civilization through, each of which unlocks new buildings, upgrades and units.  Each of these presents you with two choices for minor gods that you can worship. Every time you choose a god(including the major god), you will unlock a god power that can be used only once (up to 3 times if you're Atlantean) as well as a mythological creature or two that are associated with your god choice + unique upgrades. These god powers can change the tide of the game entirely.Each civilization is completely different in their design, and there can be differences between identical major gods as well thanks to the minor god system.The units classes featured are infantry, cavalry, archers, siege, heroes, mythological creatures and ships. The game makes these interact in a rock-paper-sciccor mechanic.The campaign is very high quality for its time, it can be highly entertaining even now, though. A total of around 50 missions is more than any RTS game will give you. The voice acting is great, though the dialouge and the plot get cheesy at points.Graphically, the shadows, the water improvements, the map texture improvements are nice, but they cannot hide the dated models and textures. I wish those had been areas of focus when it comes to visual improvements. The lighting is terrible in a few cases, so I would recommend turning the "lights on units" option off, as it's the worst of all new features. FXAA and water refraction aren't too helpful either, but to each their own.The multiplayer is awesome design vise. A multitude of game modes, custom scenarios (aka minigames), supremacy(standard mode), deathmatch(high starting resources, all upgrades researched) etc will definitely keep you hooked for months, if not years. Multiplayer performance, while improved via patches, is still not perfect, but definitely playable. Just make sure you don't run on an integrated graphics card. If you have both an integrated card and a dedicated one in your system, make sure the game defaults to the dedicated one via your driver.As for the competitiveness of multiplayer, ranked games are available via a matchmaking system that will attempt matching you against player of similar skill. Most, if not all methods of abusing the system have been dealt with by the developers.Overall I am happy with the game, but it could have been so much better. Rating it below:Graphics: 5/10Single player content: 10/15Multiplayer content: 12/15Music, sounds: 10/10Moddability, replayability: 11/15Stability, bugs: 5/15E-sport features (replays, observer mode): 8/10Cost/value: 7/10Final score: 68%

content:
r 1, 2014
												I wrote a review for this a while back, and I can say with confidence many issues have been sorted out, but some are still persistent.If you have never played this game, I am going to say right now to buy this game and play it. The campaign and its storyline is great, the factions are unique and well fleshed out and balance, for the most part, is achieved with some minor discrepencies/exploits which with experience can be learned to be countered.I will say that the game is not in its glory days anymore as this IS a re-release of a fairly old title. But the multiplayer is also active enough to have a competitive community and there is a revival in the scenario community to experience a taste of the legacy of AoM mapmakers, I suggest looking on http://aom.heavengames.com/downloads/ for more or the Steam workshop downloads provided.But lets start with the actual meat of the game for anyone reading for determining whether to buy this:The Extended Edition brings many new improvements over old Age of Mythology and the Titans expansion included, water and other graphics are overhauled and improved significantly. Graphics in general have been improved over the original and the game looks much more vibrant and detailed. This makes playing the singleplayer campaign, which is still one of the better campaigns of an RTS I have played, much more enjoyable.A new online server is also available for multiplayer gameplay and while its nowhere even close to the glory days of ESO in terms of activity and the amount of scenario makers, some old faces are there both in competitive gameplay and with old mapmakers, and some newer map makers such as myself have been sprouting up. In terms of connection these days it really depends on whose actually in the game but as long as you're computer isn't a toaster your connection and running of this game should go forward without a hitch.However there is still some bugs that are highly irritating that remain. Desync errors still happen too frequently for my tastes and this wouldn't be so much a problem if it didn't lower the rating of those involved in ranked matches. When someone is on the verge of victory and then a desync error occurs to make them lose rating... its understandable someone would be angry.There is also more visible lag and connection issues between players then there was on the old AoM in certain instances, such as on certain scenarios or with people with very bad connection to begin with. And the Extended Edition is notable in how it actually lags your computer- some of us may remember we could browse the internet with Age of Mythology running in windowed mode or running other programs while we wait for a game; while this isn't prevented and is still possible the speed of which you do so is stifling and I would not recommend it at all now. (Nor would I recommend it in matches even back then, but if you're in lobby just idling, waiting for your friend to host that game...)I suggest if you are buying this, do not play on your toaster or similar dinosaur computer, this is an updated version of Age of Mythology meant to be played on semi modern machines.And as for scenario editors who wish to return to making maps for this game: The online multiplayer community is in desperate need of scenario revival. There is scenarios still being played from time to time but the newer population of competitive players is either unaware of most of the maps or simply do not host them, mostly the former. As for the editor itself, for all intents and purposes its more or less the same as what we know, but there is some notable differences now.The differences boil down to some old trigger techniques not working, and now causing horrible lag. The old trick of looping Move Army To to move your spawned units to a location, looping it within the trigger editor now causes horrible lag and no longer just simply makes them keep moving there. It acts as if the computer stops their units and tells them to move there, acting as if the loop was just restarting and stopping the order instead of merely continuing it as it did in the past.There is also UI changes to the editor, and while the function is largely the same it takes a bit getting used to. I can say with confidence though the editor is still fairly user friendly and easy to learn, though trying to find experienced mappers to help you with your project is a little difficult in terms of looking on the lobby- you'll have to consult various forums like AoM heaven or pitch it on the steam forums for this game somewhere. I myself can help with things too, and even old legends like Nottud are still around if you look...So it boggles down to this, overall: Should you buy this game if you are new, and should you buy this game if you already have age of mythology, the original and its expansion, to relive your nolstalgia?If you are new, refer to the top. Yes. If you are an old and musty returning player like me, Yes, but don't expect it to be total brass and shine throughout the entire game. There is some grime to be worked out with this still but I can say with confidence there has been legitimate work and attention on this game to improve it and fix bugs.(p.s Potato, if you review my review im going to shoot you and feed you to a chimera, not only was your review pointless, it was awful in its critique and if anything uninformative. No one cares about grammar to that extent, it's all about presentation, and the clarity of my review was fine. That is all :D )

content:
2014
												I have been playtesting Age of Mythology: Extended Edition for a week, played over 30h, and yes, the game is worth it. If you are at least marginally into RTS, this is a game you shouldn't miss.If you are new to AoM, you're in for a good old real-time strategy experience that shaped the world of RTS gaming, all in a fun mythological setting. Specific mechanics like god powers and mythological units make the gameplay unique and interesting, bringing different style, but with the same basics, to the whole of "Age of" franchise, the paragon of strategy gaming.If you played the original, you're going to get the same great gaming experience, but with some extra goodies. Obvious are enhanced graphics and support of today's resolutions (I've been playing on 1920x1200 with no problems) - the graphics take a while getting used to as there are some harder to discern things due to the new lighting and colour scheme of map backgrounds, but overall the change is nice and adds to the game, making it more attractive for first timers.The most important addition is revitalisation of multiplayer through Steam, which looks just like old ESO. You have Quick Search for random matchmaking, advanced games for all your fun and scenario games, chat lobby and they added Leagues and Events. They've also included Treaty mode (ceasefire until certain amount of time) and the option to disable Titans (the unit). You can check the video I made about the Multiplayer Online Lobby


YouTube™ Video: Age of Mythology: Extended Edition Online Multiplayer Lobby 

			Views: 8,095		

			A comprehensive playtesting look at the online multiplayer lobby (aka new ESO) for Age of Mythology: Extended Edition. Quick search, advanced games, ladders, chats... All there!		

Another fun thing is the Steam Workshop and the fact the game has been made more friendly to modders. AoM community has always been full of talented people producing fun and useful content like various UIs and custom scenarios, and even before launch, there are mods already trickling in. Plus most of the original custom scenarios should work even on AoM:EE, so no real way to get bored with this game :-)Last thing in need of mentioning is improved support of Observer Mode and streaming - you can now see various in-game stats of players like resources, upgrades in process and similar in an easy to navigate table to give you a better idea of how are the players doing, and you can also switch to players' perspectives. This same interface works in recorded games, so you can analyse even those.All in all a nice remake of a great game. If you loved the original, you'll enjoy this, if this is your first time with AoM, you'll enjoy it, too :-)If you'd like to see the game in action, check my livestream http://www.twitch.tv/blackaddersplays and the videos on my YouTube https://www.youtube.com/BlackAddersPlays

er 12, 2016
												I first bought this game on CD, (Age of Mythology: Titan's Expansion Gold Edition). When I played it, I found it to be one of the best games I have ever played and to this day it still is. This type of brilliant RTS game is sadly practically dead. Which makes this game a must-have for anyone who is looking for a gem. The campaign for both Age of Mythology and then the Titan's Expansion are both amazing. I am a person who usually does not play the campaign's since they are far from enjoyable. Yet this storyline will make you want to play it, you will want to know what is going to happen next.Why did I hit "Not Recommend" then? Very simple, "Age of Mythology: Extended Edition." These new developers are a insult and a slap in the face to a brilliant game. I went and bought the Extended Edition when I heard a new DLC was coming out. When I play Extended Edition, some of the textures they have "enhanced" look far worse. I could not believe the terrible lighting and how awful the Hades States for the Temple looks. It is like a slap in the face to the Greek gods. The DLC is far worst, next to all the "new" units are actually just reskins of units from the other factions! I have continued to hear that the campaign is buggy and terrible. If this DLC was a mod, I would have deleted it and gave it a thumbs down for no effort. I refuse to play the new DLC and ruin my image of this beautiful game that has already been tainted by these amateurs...What I recommend you do? Go and buy :Age of Mythology: Titan's Expansion" or "Age of Mythology: Gold Edition".  It is only $10-$15 and you will like the untainted version so much more. I love this game and I would love to see it continued, but not by these childish developers who have no respect for this game or doing a honest day's work.

												I was fooled by myself, thinking this would be a great Extension to AOM, I feel that the developers and the people who worked on this (Sky box) have cashed in, knowing people will buy this regardless if they polish it well or badly because of nostalgia and the sly meta critic score that was taken from the original release several years ago. They knew there were going to be problems with this game upon release, it is disgusting to think that any company would release a product which is not up to scratch especially since the game was already released. I didn't pay the already expensive price to play a beta of a game that already exists. They have not delivered in my opinion, the AI is still terrible, the Multiplayer is lagging (reason I bought this game) and the frame rate is questionable for a game like this, the lighting effects are nothing special if not distracting and the menus are different (compared to the originals) but either way, re-mastered or not, the menus fulfilled their purpose, to be menus. I don't see how this warrants at £20 price tag. To make matters worse me and my friends are encountering problems with the steam overlay which is hindering our multiplayer experience. The steam workshop is also not working.I do not recommend buying this until the price drops and the problems with it are fixed, I will not trust this company again I thought AOE2 should have been a good indication of how they handle projects like these, I feel silly to have used the benefit of the doubt.Age of Mythology (when it is working) however is an excellent strategy game for competitive play, the multiplayer is excellent and the different civilizations are unique in terms of units, technologies and strategies that can be applied, it makes for a fresh experience on an age old formula, If only they continued after Age of Empires 3.

content:
, 2015
												While an old game now I still have fun jumping on it here and there and having a few games with friends of against the AI. For people who have yet to play this game, don't be put off by the mythological theme. 


Age of Mythology: Extended Edition 
A Screenshot of Age of Mythology: Extended Edition
By: รкг๏๏ℓ๏๏รε




This is still a great game that will give you the same satisfaction that you have gotten from the other titles. The campaign is fun and quite a lengthy investment. The expansion added campaign following the original is fantastic as well. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=353515278You can live without the dwarves focused one, while it has some fun ideas for maps it's short, easy and lacks any real depth . The main problem I had with these in the newest steam version was that the graphical quality seems to have been dramatically reduced.The day and night cycle is over rated and really serves no point, if anything I found it broke the game up more and turned it off. Multiplayer is fun but expect to play against strong players. Random AI matches are the same as before but with two new game types. They can be fun but I've always been a conquest or occasionally supremacy fan. Overall it's basically the same game that it was in the past. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=353515262The steam community seems to have produced a nice array of new mods to enjoy and I've had fun revisiting this game once again. If you are considering repurchasing this game, wait for a sale and pick it up cheap, it's the same game. If you are looking at this game for the first time and enjoy similar games in the "age of" series you should enjoy this title and get your money's worth from it but it may seem a little dated at first.

content:
0, 2014
												If you are looking for a multiplayer RTS, and your internet speed isn't incredible, move along. That said, if you are interested in single player or have amazing internet connection, go right ahead. In Short - There is a compounded latency issue. Animation quality is directly proportional to connection quality. One player with a bad connection (Or a large number of players) will slow your game. And when it slows down your game, it slows down everything causing animations to lag and glitch. They’ve updated the server client code in the Extended Edition, where they didn't need to (causing terrible bugs).In Long: Instead of a dedicated server setup. AOM now uses a peer to peer connection. The Pros are that you don't need to create servers, or port forward. But the downside is that the next iteration of the game cannot continue until every player has received information from every other player. This means that with more players, more information is required to be sent before a game iteration occurs. Additionally, with one player with a high latency, that latency affects every single player within the game. Currently with this problem, AOM game speed slows down, affecting EVERY SINGLE ELEMENT OF GAMEPLAY. This includes MODEL ANIMATION (Imagine bad connection = laggy and glitchy character models). However, this game would have been fine it they either: When the game speed is slowed down, change the timings of the model animations to match the new game speed (Just play on lightning speed to compensate).…Or just kept the old dedicated server engine for AOM.It saddens me that I cannot play this game reasonably with my friends, and I don’t want others to be disappointed. Considering that we all pre-paid, none of us can get a refund for the game we bought. That said, if you are interested in single player or have amazing internet connection, go right ahead.

er 5, 2015
												Age of Mythology: EE is a reprise of the oldschool AoM: Titans, incorporating many online features thanks to the Steam platform the game manages to come back to life easing out the task of playing with other players around the world which is always a refreshing thing to do when it comes to replaying really oldschool games.Graphically the improvs of the game aren't as shocking as the multiple previews we had through the years this was being announced, but its something, and its nice, decent.The game on its core is better balanced, and the gameplay has some nifty improvements to offer.The main issue is the performance. Somehow the game manages to run poorly on most systems, with huge frame drops, and the games unability to run from certain common graphic cards, and only from integrated graphics. Which drops the framerate and overall responsiveness even more. To the point that is actually hard to enjoy.Even if there aren't much changes graphically/gameplay wise to be called "Extended Edition" its a shame such cool online features are being hindered by the inability to correctly address the performance issues that were promised to be tackled since the launch itself.If you really enjoy RTS games, and you love AoM, and you're sure your system's performance will overcome the game issues then you will have a good time.Otherwise. Stay Away.

content:
er 29, 2015
												TL:DR version - I like age of mythology as a game, but this remake kind of sucks.TL:ohgawdwhyareyoustilltalking version...Alright, let's start with what makes age of mythology great! As a game, it's wonderful and has stood the test of time. You have a wide array of very different strategies and tactics you can use, the different races all feel substantially unique from one another, and you can pick various major and minor deities to worship which each tweak your play style to suit your individual preferences better!The units are fairly unique from one another, there's lots of interesting mythological things like giants, pegasi, sphinxes and so on, and the economic aspects are rather enjoyable as well, which is rare for a strategy game. For an example of the economic stuff, look to the egyptians who can have their pharoah empower a building to make it build faster or boost the resources given to it, or that the atlanteans carry carts with them so they don't have to wander all the way back to town to drop off resources.There's always sort of a rock/paper/scissors thing going on, and no one unit is overpowered... buuuuut. Ah, yeah, there's always a but isn't there? It's a big fat butt in this case. Several of them.Well, some of what I just mentioned isn't super accurate. A lot of the units are very, very similar with little difference at all other than their stats - special abilities are pretty much reserved for mythological units and the god powers can only be invoked once per game instead of on a cooldown so they're not that impressive most of the time. Generally speaking, your units may look different and be better tasks, but one soldier is pretty much the same as any other soldier, other than what they do bonus damage against.That's another issue... the "balance" of the game, if you can call it that, is kind of wonky. If you look to other strategy games, such as the blizzard games of warcraft 3 or starcraft 1 or 2, the difference between being "good" against another unit or "bad" is generally 150% normal damage vs 50% normal damage in return. It's a significant difference and makes it possible for masses of units to fight things they're not that good against so long as you severely outnumber them. In AoM... well, you get things like a x15 damage multiplier... it's kind of absurd. If you aren't fighting something you deal bonus damage to, you may as well not be fighting at all.This balance also has the problem that the "rock, paper scissors" moteif that AoM has going for it kind of breaks down with mythological units. Oh, you like your sphinxes? Too bad. Sure, they look big and strong, with much higher stats than normal infantry... but if the enemy has even a single hero, the bonus damage from heroes to myth units is so absurd that you may as well never bother making myth units. Especially against the greeks who have some of the most powerful and cheapest heroes which take forever to kill since nothing does bonus damage against heroes. The game claims normal infantry are the counter to heroes, but they really aren't.The AI and mechanics make turtling not an overly useful strategy as well - all, literally all defensive structures deal piercing damage, and siege weapons usually have 80-99% resistance to piercing. Walls are easily destroyed, and the AI just sends wave after wave after wave of the same small units over and over so you'll probably never be able to rebuild a wall once it's damaged, even with the silly fast building speed in the game. So if you like to turtle and just tech up for long periods of time, you're going to find it's a nuisance - not difficult, just annoying, especially since the AI tends to ignore military units to attack peasants mindlessly. You can work around those things, but it's irritating instead of fun.Still, the game is fun as a whole. There's no denying that. As strategy games go, even for the minor nuisances it has, it's still one of the best, and by far the best of the age of empires series by leaps and bounds over any other. Yeah, the game balance is a bit wonky, but it sorta kinda works still. Really, it's fun in a way that more serious games like starcraft aren't. Starcraft II has by far a better campaign mode, but honestly I'd say the skirmishes in AoM are vastly superior to the skirmishes in SC2 surprisingly enough, and I have a platinum rating on SC2 so make of that what you will.So if the game's still very fun after so many years... what's wrong with it? Why the downvote?Well... this version... sucks, to put it mildly.Example: do you have a computer that can run Evolve at 120FPS? Well expect to have dips below 10FPS on AoM.The "new features" are things that honestly have no real impact on the game. A tiny little mini campaign is kinda... nice I guess? But let's be honest, the vast bulk of a strategy game's lifespan and value comes from its skirmish mode which this doesn't change in the slightest. The day night cycle is... negligible, as is much of everything else.The glitches that are brought, such as crashes, freezing, framerate drops, and actually a significantly reduced AI kind of diminish the game. The original was better because it actually worked. This version... you've got a 50/50 chance of finishing a mission without it being finished for you by a glitch of some sort or another. These bugs have been around for over a year now, so don't expect them to ever get patched.The price point is also a major issue - I was annoyed enough as it was that AoM was still trying to charge $20 when it was a decade old. Then they came out with the "extended" version... and now they want over $35 for it. Yeaaaaaaaaaaahno. Get it on sale, but that's it.Actually, you know what? Buy AoM: extended edition on sale... and then download a hacked copy of the original after you've paid for this one, and play the hacked one instead because it's flat out going to play better than this. That's right, I just told you to pay for the game but play a hacked one. That should tell you something about the quality of the game - the game itself is fine, but this version isn't worth the paper it's printed on. Oh, it's a computer title. It's not printed on paper. Yeaaaah it's worth less than $0 as it is.Oh well.But I didn't get the chance to pay for AoM when it first came out years ago, and honestly, AoM as a game is worth paying for to encourage further development of games such as this. Seriously, support AoM:EE simply because if enough people do, maybe they'll make a sequel. Yeah, the extended edition sucks, yeah, it doesn't deserve your money, and yeah, a hacked version of the original is simply the better game... but AoM itself deserves a reward for existing, even if they dropped the ball on this one. Into the sewer. Sorry, I don't have hip waders, I'm not going to go dig it out of the slime and sewage.If you do, however, have the hip waders? It's a magnificient game beneath a veneer of crap, so if you can wash it off, it's well worth it. I just can't recommend this release is all. Even at -75% off.

content:
, 2014
												Age of Mythology: Extended Edition as a real-time strategy game published by Microsoft. It is a perfected version of the old game Age of Mythology and Age of Mythology: The Titans.Age of Mythology: Extended Edition gameplay are pretty much the same as the old Age of Mythology and Age of Mythology: The Titans made into one game. In addition, the Golden Gift add on are also included in this remake. Unlike Age of Empires II: HD Edition, Age of Mythology: Extended Edition doesn't have population cap increase, everything in the gameplay stays the same. It's quite nostalgic to replay this old game with improved graphics, I remember almost all the god powers I used, the meteor rain, tornado, earthquake and more. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition also comes with Steam Cloud support and Steam Workshop support, which is a great addition into the game.Age of Mythology: Extended Edition however, have improved graphics than the old game. New improved global lightning, widescreen support, new water shaders and the new day and night cycle in skirmish play. It looks prettier now and more epic to play. With all these improved visuals, Age of Mythology: Extended Edition still retain its great performances and runs very great and smooth.Age of Mythology: Extended Edition exact same gameplay can be its good side or bad side for some people. But for me, it's very nostalgic and fun. I prefer this kind exact same gameplay rather than some of those next generation game with many promises which turn out to be a disappointment. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is indeed a great remake. I recommend this.Rating 9/10

												There are many features which make the game great. I'm gonna name a few:- beautiful randomly generated maps. You can learn everything you need to know about the maps in 2 hours, but even after 30 days of playing they will still surprise you.- the playable cultures excel with their diversity and fascinating mythology. Unleash terrifying mythical brutes such as the einherjer which will tear your enemies apart.- Advancing on the map with your siege army and military camps adds a lot to the 'all out war' feeling to the game.- The soundtrack, the graphics and the overall design make for a true atmospheric environment.Age of Mythology was the game that initally ignited my passion for online games. It's hard for me to be objective, because I share so many glorius childhood memories with this classic jewel. The main reason I bought the extended edition for steam were simple: The game hasn't aged and they gave access to online-playing. The former AoM servers were unfortunately shut down which was a huge bummer at the time.

So while i leave a negative review here - i can really recommend this game for old times sake if it is going cheap in the sale.

content:
, 2014
												THIS is a review of the "Extended Edition" not the original Age of Mythology.    Age of Mythology: Extended Edition has minor improvements and major issues compared to the original game. The whole thing...it's not even close to a rework. Why would you make a reboot of a 12 years old game and still not make any major changes except the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ water? The only things that are new are some trading cards and twitch integration that has no point in this game. Why not? Well, it's because the multiplayer is barely playable due to the massive lag in any kind of server. Even when it says it has 50 ping. What impressed me was that I had read about a guy complaining about lag in LAN! Can you believe this? The developers - Skybox Labs just ruined the whole conception of gameplay in the Extended Edition.  Do you know what else is arrogant about the game? The price. Who would pay 28 (I can even say 30) euro for poorly developed reboot of a 12 years old game? It's worse than the original one which is much better and even cheaper.   Aside from the horrible reboot, Age of Mythology is a great game. It's a RTS game with the similar gameplay of Age of Empires. The game can be very competitive as almost every RTS game and the gameplay is amazing. The campaign mode has an interesting story with almost every element of the mythology. The game was my childhood game and I love it but I deny anything good in the Extended Edition since it's only playable vs bots.   Don't waste that much money on a reboot. It's even slowly dying every day after people saw what a tragedy it is. From top 100 games in steam on the release in the 7-8 place, it got kicked from the chart with thousands of people dissapointed.

content:
, 2014
												At the current game state (as of 10/05/2014), the game handles like a donkey with broken legs; total trash. For (what seems to be) the majority of players, the game handles and runs poorly. Constant lagging, freezing and hanging that slows down the PC as a whole and can cause it to lock up.I've tried many things for numerous hours to try and get this classic RTS to work. To name a few,XP Compatibility, Admin mode, trouble-shooting with all sorts of options and settings in-game and in steam, folder read/write permission/rights, defragging, PC cleaning (registry files for example) and nothing made a difference. Sometimes right away or a couple minutes (at best) after I launch the game, the lag started and it just got worse and worse to the point where my whole PC would freeze up and I'd need to manually terminate the game exe' file through the Task Manager.Bitter I may sound, and disappointed I am. I do not recommend purchasing this game as of yet. Perhaps (and hopefully) the game will be patched and fixed in the future. But as of yet; it isn't worth the gamble to see if you're part of the minority that can run the game just fine.

content:
er 11, 2014
												Three trolls, four golden battle boars and a pack of wolves have just devastated the last of Thor's town centres, and my gatherers have already moved in to take over their farming network. I am Odin, and my thunder god son had the audacity to attack me during the opening 30 minutes of this random map skirmish.The ludicrousness of this scenario, as mythical creatures of various origins trundle in over peaceful farmland to murder everyone in sight, was Mythology's strength over Ensemble's Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings when it was released in 2002. Mythology's colourful range of high-level fantasy creatures make the final act of any skirmish much more exciting than units of historical repute did in Age of Kings. Kraken trouble the seas, dragon-like nidhoggs circle the skies and hydra grow a head for every enemy they slay.Age of Mythology does feel antiquated, but it is still a lot of fun. It wasn't a notably innovative RTS at release, mostly built on '90s ideas, but it did take Ensemble's blend of Civ-style city management and more conventional military RTS ideas to its creative peak, as well as making the series fully 3D for the first time.The upgraded effects of the Extended Edition, most noticeably the shiny-looking water, help contemporise Mythology, but the character models are the strongest signs that this is a decade-old game. AI is a bit of an issue, too. On a moderate difficulty, the enemies attack predictably in medium-sized waves while rarely putting up an overwhelming defence of their own territories.I don't hold that against Mythology, though, because it is still cathartic to steamroll the AI on random maps. The online multiplayer, too, means you won't be short on smarter opponents, and it seems to be running well, even if the process of finding a game you can join feels a bit arduous.The Extended Edition isn't short on single-player content, either. Collected here are the Titans expansion and the shorter Golden Gift DLC campaign, in addition to the original's mammoth story mode.Each campaign level is prefaced by in-engine cutscenes of hilariously low production values. Voice acting sounds like the product of three almost-drunk friends being handed the keys to a recording studio for an afternoon. This shortfall is probably another sign of its age and the industry standard of the time, but otherwise I think this is one of the better RTS campaigns of its day in the variety of the mission structure.You rarely feel like you're doing the exact same thing twice, and the parameters can change from survival to deathmatches and surprise ambushes. The impressively in-depth Scenario Editor helps to extend the singleplayer's lifespan, and with Workshop support, there's no fear of running dry of stuff to do.Age of Mythology still has a lot of value beyond nostalgia.This isn't a total remake, so don't go in expecting one. The Extended Edition is still a really well-paced and entertaining RTS, one that revels in over-the-top imagery and remains a one-off in subject matter within the oeuvre of the sadly departed Ensemble.

content:
1, 2016
												Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a good example of a poorly made cash grab.The Extended tag probably means the new bugs Skybox Labs managed to produce, that didn't exist in the original.The AI pathfinding is messed up. Units often phase/clip through the walls and villagers often get stuck in larger buildings (Temple, Wonder, Titan Gate) they have finished building.The changes to the graphics are highly questionable. The new textures are washed out and blurry, so it's highly recommended to revert them to something that looks closer to the original (EG: Epic textures mod). Otherwise you will have a hard time finding your units, as they blend into the environment too well. Last but not least the netcode. Oh, boy! If you thought Age of Empires 2 HD's netcode was bad, then you have no idea what this game has in store for you. The online matches are insane lagfests, often freezing up for  seconds, rendering the game unplayable.Bottom line is that this version of the game is a mess. Skip it, you're not missing out much!

content:
er 27, 2016
												The hours played on Steam pale greatly with the amount of hours I have put into this game. Still owning it in a hard copy...This is one of those games I always come back to.Not because the story is any good, it's the equivalent of a Hercules or Xena episode.Not because the gameplay is revolutionary.Not because of cutting edge graphics...So why?It's fun.It allows us to interact with myths and mythology in a way that's surprisingly rare.It is an RTS with a solid base building mechanic.The factions are unique from one another with those factions being further seperated by a multitude of minor god selections which help diversify and specialize your force.The game mostly works (in a generally) on a rock/paper/scissors mechanic...with mythological units (like a Minotaur or a Sphinx) eat up basic normal units, your hero units (say an egyptian pharaoh or Hercules) beat myth units and your basic normal human units beat hero units.The game does have its faults. Obviously the graphics aren't the best. The story is below average, the base building mechanics are from another time but you get to have Hercules knocking around giants while on another part of the map a sphinx unit spins to win on a structure.As with most games I'll recommend, snag it on sale but ultimately I suggest you give it a chance.

y 2
												I used to think this was a nice improvement, but after a 100 hours and comparing with the original I have a few things to say.The game looks nice, but at the same time, non of the units were improved and the terain got dark and ugly after a while. Then it started to show that because of a lack of improvements in certain areas, the game looks worse because there is a beatiful shadow on the ground of a pixelated tree.Now this I would have overlooked, was it not for the fact that they also tampered with the game in terms of pricing and new units, and the God awful expansion which starred a huge baby gnome as the "Titan of the Chinese". The expansion gets in your face if you don't own it since there are some balance changes to accomodate it. Yet there  are no balance changes to the fact that Zeus will defenestrate your buildings like no tomorrow, or the fact that the atlanteans are all unbalanced as Britains Pound right now.But yet, I would overlook this. For these things are things I could live with if only I had a multiplayer that actually worked. And ofcourse, no it doesn't. Frequent desync issues, people randomly getting thrown out of games and general latency issues plague the multiplayer. Almost nobody plays the game multiplayer anymore anyway.It was here when I became desperate for some AOM, so I played tutorial and fought things in skirmishes. It was all fine and dandy, until I loaded up Acropolis and found to my horror that all the plateaus had gaps in the clif faces which completely ruined one of my favourite maps. I then started up the origional and played one skirmish game and it felt like I was playing Age of Mythology again. No lag, no weird shadows, no weird inconsistencies in graphical quality, no weird streched out faces, no weird skewed camera in cutscenes. Most of all it ran buttery smooth, so much so that I was supprised at how well I could actually play. I did the same thing as I normally but this time I turned out to have improved. My conclusion is that this is only worth it if you want to play with friends abroad and want an official way to do so, and don't mind any conectivity issues. This by no means is a good replacement for Age of Mythology, a game which worked fine but had some flaws. These issues are why I can't recommend this game as a replacement.

content:
15, 2016
												Short version - DO NOT BUY THIS GAME, even if you used to be a fan. The amateur developers have completely destabilized and destroyed the game.Long version - I've never written a review before, but my recent experience with Age of Mythology has driven me to it.Let me start out by saying that I've been playing this game since it originally came out and I've loved it the whole time. The campaign is incredible, the graphics are great for their time, and the strategy gameplay is the best I've ever seen. It's rare not to get bored of a game after playing it for 14 years, and I'd go as far as saying that AOM is my favourite game of all time.The old AOM that is... Recently a set of wannabe developers have released DLC that is absolute crap, or at least that's what I've read in reviews, which is why I haven't bought the DLC. I figured I just wouldn't buy it and continue to enjoy the same game that I've enjoyed for years.Of course, the old AOM had some bugs, but they were minor and the game was stable over all. Everything was fine until the fascist developers of this new DLC started screwing around with the original game! They've removed some technologies and units and added new ones, they've reskinned some things (and did a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ job), and they've introduced a ton of bugs to the gameplay. For example, god powers show up in the area for researching upgrades when you click on buildings like the wall and temple, technologies that you research show up in the wrong buildings or not at all, and when you drag to select units, the bottom area of the screen which shows who and what you selected either shows the wrong number of units, the wrong units, or nothing at all.I paid to get the original Age of Mythology and the Steam version worked fine before, but the bugs these ameteurs introduced have turned the game into a steaming pile of you-know-what. If you want to add units and other new content, that's fine. Release it as a mod so that when people install it and it completely destroys the game, it's their fault they ruined it and not yours.To summarise, even if you are a fan of the old AOM, don't buy this game, because sadly it's not the game you played back in the day. I really hope the developers get their ♥♥♥♥ together and stop ruining this classic.

content:
er 24, 2016
												I got this game on 12/22/2016. After reading the numerous reviews about how I should not buy this game and play aom on voobly instead, I decided to go ahead and buy it anyway since I love aom (1800 rr back in 07' ;) ). I suppose I just was not satisfied because the reviews did not actually go into detail about anything that I thought was important. I am going to do my best, though, to give you the details of how terribly disappointing this game has been for me for the past couple days, even though I don't tend to give bad reviews because I don't like hurting other people's businesses, However, I consider this game a scam.I'm going to start with the China campaign, since that's where I started. The first issue arose when I restarted the first scenario, since I was kinda screwing around with looking at the new units and the AI got ahead of me. When I restarted, I was astonished to find that I was in the Archaic Age, rather than the Classical Age, like I had been in the game before. In addition, once I collected 400 food and built my first temple, I could not even advance to the Classical Age. Therefore, I was stuck trying to fight the AI with immortals from my town center, which was basically impossible once they started sending in human units. I restarted again and again, but could not resolve the issue. I decided to finally restart the whole game and wait out the cinematic all the way through again, and I finally got the game to start in the Classical Age. I can't say for sure that this bug exists within the game or if there is an issue with my computer. However, I reinstalled a fresh version of windows 8.1 about a week ago and there's basically nothing on my computer, so if it's a problem with my computer, then that's really a problem with poor compatability caused by the developers. The other possibility is it could be an issue caused by the Ekanta user interface mod that I dowloaded for, and I actually haven't tested that yet. However, Ekanta is a popular UI and I would be surprised if no one figured that out yet. After beating the first and the second scenarios, I got to the third, when I discovered that I once again could not advance to the classical age, despite having a temple and 400 food. I thought that this possibly could be like the original AOM campaign, which don't let you advance (although the option doesn't even show up for those), but was once again flooded by human units and forced to fight with the only unit I could make, which were immortals from my town center. This time I restarted and restarted and no matter what could not begin in whatever age i was supposed to, or resolve whatever the issue was this time. However, i couldn't advance, and did the only thing I could which was build my TC and either THRILL OF VICTORY, or spam O CANADA bears (recommend the O CANADA's if you run into this issue). I can't remember the order of the campaign past this because I just wanted to get it over with. Another one of the scenarios (there are only like 9 of these but they are almost all terrible) has you fight off an army. This time, when I restarted I discovered that my troops went from having heavy upgrades to having no upgrades. This bug has an easy fix, though, If you just restart and wait for part of the cinematic to finish before skipping; then your troops will once again be heavily armored. The final bug with the campaign that I ran into so far was once again that I could not age on another scenario, this time after building an armory since I actually started in the Classical Age. I was eventually able to beat the AI's champion, fully upgraded units with my clasical units after mixing in some monkey king myth units. So that ends most of what I want to say about the campaign. The final issue I want to bring up comes from watching a streamer play as thor against a chinese player in a 1v1. Once he got to the mythic age, he discovered that he mentioned that he had no units that could counter cataphract, which are Chinese counter-infantry cavalry, without also being countered by the cataphract themselves. Norse does not have an archer or a cavalry unit which counters cavalry, which would be the only two options, unless using myth units. Thanks for reading and please don't buy this game!

number of helpful: 15 of 20 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
												I was a bit hesitant to buy this game. It has quite a BIG pricetag, especially keeping in mind that it's a 2002 game. A few months after release a sale came, I took a deep breath and bought the game. I have to admit I was quite surprised and astonished. Despite all the bad critiques the remake is getting the game works like a charm. The visuals are beautiful, the gameplay is fluid and bug free. Even though there are known performance-eaters like SSAO and FXAA/BLOOM added to the game Age of Mythology still runs like what you'd expect from a 2002 game, except with better graphics. I'd put it between AOE HD (which looks horrid in my opinion, despite the "HD" tag) and AOE III.However the looks aren't everything.Gameplay-wise (surprisingly) it's very much like the Age of Empires games, you can plow through several campaigns which mainly consists of gathering supplies, building a city (or two), fending off smaller enemy attacks, garrisoning a huge army and then defeating the enemy. It's a bit like Civilization on a more smaller "local" scale. However the main difference from the Age of Empires games is the addition of:- Epic Gods- Magic powers- Kickass monsters, mythological creatures to add to your army!The workshop is filled with great content, great texture pags to further enhance the looks of the game, small fixes and additions to the UI etc. The integration of the mods into the game is seamless. I heard that it also has a great mod development kit (I haven't tried it yet). Probably the only negative thing about the game is that many people are having issues with the multiplayer, server lag. I like playing strategy games at my own pace so I can't reinforce these criticisms, I haven't tried the multiplayer.To keep a long story short I think the developers really added extra "oomph" to an old classic spicing it up enough to be appealing even after 12 years. It's really up to you if you think the price-tag (which I admit is quite thick) is justifiable or you'll wait for it to go on a sale like I did. Right after I bought this game I played four hours straight without even noticing the time. I think that's enough recommendation, especially today when we (including me) just hoard up dozens of games without even trying them.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2014
												Age of Mythology is Real Time Strategy game that has managed to achieve the rare aspect of balance in its gameplay. Picking and sticking to an 'overpowered god' from the start is not really possible, as gods are very much rock-paper-scissors with each other. You can pick a certain god that counters the Norse (Gaia, for example) which would be destroyed by the Greek. You do get the feeling as you go along that certain Gods have better abilities than others, although I feel this is largely down to personal perference. Loki for example, has the ability for his Hersirs to randomly spawn Myth units into the battle, which maybe considered 'OP' by those who are in a militaristic war against them. BUT, Hersirs are very weak to arrows. Gather a few archers and you're back in the game. But then they can build calvary. But then you can build spearmen, and it continues.In terms of units, there isn't that much variety however it is not necessarily the units that you pick, but how you build the groups. When playing as the Greeks, two horseman, two archers and two infantry will survive longer than six archers.I played this game many years ago and am happy to see it make a HD relaunch, however honestly there really isn't much difference. My main 'pet peeve' with this game is the online play which, to be brutally honest, frustrates me to no end. There are three aspects which irritate me, those being; 1) Sync errors. You can be 40 minutes into a game and you will suddenly get a pop up saying 'Saving: Sync Error' which is an 'oh ****' moment. Your 40 minutes is now worthless, as you will now be back at the Main Menu screen. What a waste of time. They offer no explanation, no 'just kick the out-synced player', EVERYONE is put back to the Main Menu with nothing to show for the last 40 minutes. Oh, and did I mention that some players use programs to force sync errors if they are losing? Yeah.2) There's no option to vote-kick players midgame. The only option you have to kick a player is when they're about to disconnect, at which point the ENTIRE game comes to a halt for 30 seconds while you all vote. The voting, by the way, is pointless. Regardless of which option you pick (Continue or Wait) you will be forced to wait the full 30 seconds, even if the vote in unanimous.3) The program itself. The program itself can randomly just shut down. You can be destroying the entire map and then your game will just suddenly shut down with no warning as if you've pressed Alt + F4. Besides the above GLARING technical errors that I am in absolute disbelief haven't been fixed after x years since the game's release, the gameplay is actually very good. This is one of the most played, soon to be the most played game in my library. I would recommend, but I wish they'd sort out the gaping holes in their ship.

content:
y 1
												I have spent an overwhelming time playing Age of Mythology back in the disk form years ago. I was overly hyped to see that Steam was picking up AOM considering I lost the disk some time ago. Let's go over the game, shall we?(This will be solely based off of Age of Mythology itself, rather than any updates or such done by the Extended Edition.)Campaign32 levels, 3 different factions, interesting heroes and a compelling story. Barely any levels are the same, with each being unique and exciting. While a few (and I mean a very few) are a tad bland, that should be no reason to turn someone away from it. Not to mention the Atlantis campaign, which adds 12 more levels to play on with another new story and heroes tying to the first campaign in many ways.SkirmishWhen playing skirmish, the game provides a fun and (admittedly slightly repetative) experience to better oneself before possibly attempting multiplayer or the campaign on a harder difficulty. The player can choose any of the factions and their respective gods, giving a nice plethora of play styles. I do recommend keeping away from the "Titan" difficulty, however, as the AI gains a lot of handicaps.MultiplayerOh boy, multiplayer. I've seen a lot of great things from it. New maps, game mods, (usually) differing play styles from other players. It offers a good zone for both new players and pros, but I do recommend avoiding many ranked matches unless you're at the top of your game, because trust me, the other player almost always is. It's a great way to spice things up if you've beaten the campaign and are tired of the AI in skirmishes.Extended Edition + China DLCThe extended edition and China DLC are honestly... Disappointing. I'd say avoid the China DLC unless you're dying for new content so badly you'd do anything for it (which I'd even recommend the workshop before the DLC). The Chinese army is very gimmicky, and everything feels reused, with little, if anything, being brand new. It's also rather buggy. I, myself, haven't even beat the campaign yet, it's just bland and boring. The Extended edition tried to amp up textures and such, but it makes some things ugly and unappealing, and I highly recommend getting a mod or two to fix these up.All in all, I say buy this game, be it the disc or the Steam version, avoid the China DLC and game on. You won't be disappointed!

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												FOR THE RECORD; Most of the negative reviews on the game aren't due to the actual mechanics and gameplay, but more to do with the terrible pricing, and the poor online netcode. If you're wanting to buy this game, DON'T BUY IT ON STEAM. Or at least wait until it's on a massive discount. Or better yet, buy a retail copy. That's the short version.Now, about the game. It's Age of Mythology. Which means it's a classic. Nuff said. The campaign is still amazing and holds up very well. The extended edition includes the Titans expansion which includes the Atlantean race, and the patched in content 'The Golden Gift' campaign. It's important to remember however that the campaign is also there to get you acquainted with the multiplayer mechanics.The multiplayer is ok, but the Netcode is wack. Lag is inevitable, and the only people who play the MP now are either vets from the original retail version who will wreck your sh**, or the odd random. My advice. Buy the game for the excellent singleplayer, and maybe jump online with a friend and get to grips with the unit intricacies, then have a go. PRO's:•	HD textures (not really noticeable) •	Excellent campaigns•	Solid balancing•	ClassicCon's:•	Dev's have abandoned the game. Horrific follow on development•	Multiple glitiches in MP. Also crashes sometimes•	AI is stupid as hell•	Insane asking priceConclusion: In my opinion, at this time the game isn't worth the Steam asking price. If you're willing to pay however, you'll have access to 3 campaigns, an editor, MP with all races, and skirmishes. All with a few HD textures. If you're not short of a few quid, you could do a lot worse than this. Pick it up if you want to try out more RTS outside of StarCraft.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 14
												This game  I owned 14 or 15 years ago and loved it. For it's time and even now its storyline, gameplay and graphics are still quite good. What it definitely gets right is it doesn't just take the basics of mythology and used the same tired old tropes. It uses all manner of characters, creatures and phenomena from the 3 Civilizations and even for me some that I weren't even aware existed. You can tell alot of research and alot of thought went into this game.- Pros -  - Relatively good graphics considering how old the game is.- Nice music- Good storyline- wide variety of characters and creatures- Creative "god powers"- many hours of play time (is not a short game)- really, really good tools for making your own map/scenario- Each Civilization has their own unique way of generating favour with the gods- Cons -- You can for the most part train a bunch of myth units that are more effective than most regular units to fight with and win- Enemy AI seemingly uses the same tactic almost every time, using small harassing skirmishes of 8-10 units at a time (at least on easy difficulty)- Seemingly the best way to give yourself a chance at winning is build as many walls and towers as you can and order your troops into defensive stance so they dont split up chasing every enemy unit they see all around the map and then dying.All in all though this game is fantasic and if you had any kind of love of Mythology before this can do nothing but rekindle it and maybe even make you want to do some reading on your favourite characters/creatures. I highly recommend this game. :)8.5/10Also a nice comedic bonus is watching a Cyclops use the special attack of picking up a humanunit and throwing it (probably) to it's death is pretty damn amusing as well. :)

content:
ry 12
												Malista!I got this game on disc over ten years ago. I got the Titans expansion as a gift a year or two afterwards, when I had fourteen teeth removed in a single operation. This is the game I played when I was stuck at home in pain all day, so forgive me if this review -is- a little biased.Even though I don't play it as much anymore, the campaigns are always a blast. I can't speak to multiplayer, however - I was never really good at that stuff anyway. The steam multiplayer community isn't *too* active, but it isn't too dead either. If I recall correctly there's actually still a pretty active Voobly community for the game.The achievements for this game are a little grindy to say the least. Having to play 1,000 online games got a little boring after a while, and it seems as if the hidden achievement for Alpaca Hour is almost impossible to get legitimately nowadays as the developers haven't switched on the toggle for it in over a year. I ended up just setting my clock back to get it.Overall... a timeless classic! For me it's well worth the price, but since most people aren't as attached to this game as I am, I'd recommend waiting for a sale before you pick this game up, which happens quite often to my knowledge.Any last quips? I wish they'd bring back the old theme music!

r 26, 2015
												I've always loved this game.When I found out it was on steam I knew that I was going to to get it immediatly.I heavily recommend for anyone who enjoys RTS game or the AOE franchise to play this game.However be wary that this game has many faults, the multiplayer is regarded by many to be the worst that steam has to offer, and has many, many bugs and glitches.If you already own a physical copy that still works or use Windows 10 it's not worth the large cost to upgrade.The graphical enhacement and "Extended features" are not anything to write home about, the graphics are formidable but are still lacking in comparrison to other games out on the steam store, the workshop intergration is a nice addition for those (Including me) who could not download mods off of the internet.This game is still amazing, and the story is amazing, the linking of all of these mythological characters was executed very well.Story: 8/10, I love it's creativity but it does rely heavily on clichés and plot holes.Gameplay: 7/10, Plays like all RTS with little veriation other than myth units and heroes.Online: 4/10, Terrible multiplayer, with the little veriety AOM had to begin with, mixed with the laggy and sometimes unplayable multiplayer it gets worse.Graphics: 6/10, Amazing compared to the original version however as I said before, they are not the best.Overall score: 7/10, Great game but bad multiplayer that damages the steam intergration.If you enjoy RTS. this game is a must have.

content:
r 7, 2016
												Love Age of Mythology. Hate extended edition and Tale of the Dragon. No one wanted this game to work more than me. There is a long list of complaints I have, some that others may disagree with. But what I think we can all find inexcusable is how broken the multiplayer is. Horrible lag, games will just crash out to menu or drop without apparent reason, etc. etc. And I know it’s not an issue with other player ping or something to that effect because you don't have the same problem playing Vanilla or Titans. I stuck around for a while hoping they would fix it. They haven't, and I don't imagine they will. If you love this game, get the original version and play on Game Ranger. You'll have a better gameplay experience and a larger community to play with (unless all your only really into is single player, in which case there is no reason to buy this anyway).Oh, and I almost forgot, new maps are literally unfinished! They have maps say it has certain features in the map menu, but the map just doesn’t have the feature at all. And when you look it up online, they just didn't to put it in OR even bother take out the text promising the feature! I mean talk about sloppy and lazy..... it’s like they were actively trying to make a ♥♥♥♥ product...

												An HD remake of the original game, the spiritual sequel to Age of empires that's more about skirmishes between heroes and monsters than it is about setpiece armies and ancient kingdoms. The game takes large departures from the Empire serie,s but stays familiar enough to be recognizeable to an outsider. The game is fantastic, and although the mythos is bigger, the scale is a bit smaller: Military units always take multiple population, restricting your army size.Nothing here will win you over if you disliked the game already, but if you were a fan then, you'll be a fan now. That said: Thirty dollars is pretty steep. I would wait for a sale.
